bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Gustaf E. Lambert, April 5, 1954

div1.p: Hench has recently found four photographs in trunks belonging to the daughter-in-law of James Carroll. He would like Lambert's help in identifying buildings and people in the photographs.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Gustaf E. Lambert, April 5, 1954
div1.opener:
April 5, 1954
Mr. Gust E. Lambert
17092 Lincoln Street
Hazel Crest, Illinois
My dear Mr. Lambert:
div1.p:
I am sorry to hear that you have been ill but glad indeed that you are re-
covering. I do not want to ask you to make a trip into town from a Chicago
suburb just after you are recovered from pneumonia. Perhaps you can help me
at the moment by correspondence.

I shall be in Chicago three different days. I shall be at the Conrad
Hilton Hotel just for the day, Sunday, April 4; again just for the day on
Friday, April 9 and on these two days I will be much too busy at medical
meetings. But I shall be returning through Chicago with my 11-year old
boy from the east on Thursday, April 15 and would certainly like to see
you then if it can be arranged. If, by then, you are feeling well enough,
you might come to town and join me for lunch perhaps or, if you are not
feeling well and I can do it, I will come to see you; however as I say,
I will have my boy with me and will have to take care of him.

Mrs. George Carroll, daughter-in-law of Doctor Carroll, recently permitted
me to go through some old trunks. I found therein some very interesting
material, especially four photographs, the likes of which I have not seen
before. Two of them I am especially anxious for you to see. Two of these
photographs were not identified. One was identified correctly and another
one was wrongly identified. I am especially anxious for you to see these.

The one, marked on the back, “A”, is, I am positive, the yellow fever huts
just across the railroad track from the post hospital. I have marked it up
with ink.

Let us proceed with the objects from right to left. “A” is undoubtedly the
little bridge across the LaPlaya railroad tracks. If so, “K” must be Building
No. 115 as indicated on the map of the post hospital grounds facing page 51
of General Truby's book, a copy of which I think you have; and “L” is un-
doubtedly Building No. 117. I know that you have had trouble with your
eyesight but I hope that with a magnifying glass you can examine this photo-
graph carefully.

According to a model of the post hospital and the yellow fever huts made years
ago by Alfonso Perez, which model is still at Carlisle Barracks, the bridge
across the railroad track was between the two rows of yellow fever huts but
nearer the row 114-120. I enclose a photograph of this model which I have
cut in half as when it was set up at Carlisle Barracks for the purposes of
this photograph, they set it up wrong. Therefore I have detached the yellow
fever huts. railroad track and bridge - in other words, the second section of
this model (it was on two separate boards). Although this model shows all
the buildings very crowded together, nevertheless I am amazed to find how
accurate the model is, as indicated by various photographs of these dif-
ferent buildings. It is on the basis of this model that I have identified
Building K as yellow fever hut No. 115 and Building L as yellow fever hut No. 117,
Lambert
- 2 -
April 5, 1954
Now, will you please consult the map on page 51 of General Truby's book.
A being the bridge, B, in my opinion, is Building No. 105, the warehouse; C is
Building 102; D (just behind E although it looks as if it might be part of E)
is probably Building 101 and E is Building 111 with F, a little unmarked building,
just to the left of it. In other words, E and F must be the disinfecting plant
and your sleeping quarters. I wonder if you have ever seen this before and if
you want one, I shall have another one made for you, enlarged. G, a dark building
behind a white tent, is probably Building No. 99; H is Building 93. “I” would
be yellow fever hut No. 113 and the little building on the horizon between the
yellow fever huts 113 and 115, would probably be Building No. 96. I am most
anxious for you to help me identify this.

Now for the people. There are at least nine and possibly two more in the group.
I wonder if you could help me identify them. You will note that one man is in
white uniform and I strongly suspect that's you. It must have been some oc-
casion when you had 8 or more visitors at once and I suspect that it is a
photograph taken when part of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board took the members
of the Havana Yellow Fever Board to see some of the experimental cases. It
looks like a pretty formal occasion. At least it looks to me as if Figure No. 9
has on a high silk hat. I am wondering if figure 3, 7 or 8 might be Walter Reed.
Behind figure No. 1 in the white uniform (which I hope is you) you will see
one man standing on the ground, Figure No. 2, and just to the right of the
figure in which there may or may not be shown part of the body of someone just
getting out of the rear of the doherty wagon. I am wondering if the tall
figure, No. 4, in what looks like a rumpled uniform, might be Doctor Carroll
and between him and figure No. 5, the stooping man in the middle wagon, I
think one sees the back of the driver

Photo B. For comparison with Photo A, I am sending you Photograph B which I
think I showed you some years ago. It is a newspaper photograph from a
Springfield, Ohio, paper of April 11, 1905, a photograph with the words, “Wards
of the Isolation Yellow Fever Hospital, Columbia Barracks, Havana, Cuba.” This
photograph is pasted, with the clipping, in Mrs. Walter Reed's own scrapbook
about her husband. Until seeing Mrs. Carroll's Photograph A, I could not be
certain which of the yellow fever huts were in Photograph B, but viewing both
pictures with a hand lens, I now believe that the huts in Photograph B are
not the same as those in Photograph A. I suspect strongly that in Photograph B
the hut on the right is No. 118, the one in the center is No. 116 and the little
one on the left by the tree is No. 114. Now look at the horizon on the ex-
treme left of this little newspaper photograph and you will see that something
rises toward the left at an angle. Looking at the bridge on the extreme right
in Photograph A, I have a strong suspicion now that this little angulation on
the horizon on the left of Photograph B is the end of the bridge, and that if
one holds Photograph B on the right next to photograph A, one has now two
photographs showing the two different rows of huts, although neither photo-
graph shows huts Nos. 119 and 120.

Another reason why I think the little building in the middle of Photograph B
is not the same as the one in the middle of Photograph A (which I have marked
Building K) is that in the front of the center building, Photograph B, there
are on either side of the door two white cross-boards extending from the ground
to the flooring and the building seems to be about as far off the ground at
Lambert
- 3 -
April 5, 1954
its rear as it is at the front but comparing this with the center building
(K), Photograph A, they don't quite look alike. First of all, there seems
to be a different slope to the ground so that the rear of Building K is
nearer the ground than the front. Furthermore, on the left of the door
of Building K only one white bar can be seen from ground to floor and no cross
bar. Unfortunately the comparable boards on the right of the door are hidden
by the barrels.

So much for Photographs A and B but please compare them with Photographs C-1
and C-2, which is the model which I have cut in half because the two dif-
ferent sections of the model (on two different boards) were put together
wrong by the photographer.

Now, please examine Photograph D. Mrs. Carroll loaned me this and on the back
was written, “Laboratory of Camp Lazear, property of Mrs. James Carroll.” The
writing is not that of Doctor Carroll. Now, there was no actual laboratory at
Camp Lazear. There was a little mosquito laboratory attached to the rear of
Building No. 2 and we know what that building looked like. Therefore this
photograph is wrongly identified and I am sure it represents the laboratory, not
at Camp Lazear, but at the post hospital at Camp Columbia. If so, it should be
Building No. 89. (It is shown in Truby's book, page 51 and when you look at
the Perez model of Building No. 89, it is identical in shape with the building
in this photograph). Please note the little front door, the sloping roof, the
cupola and, most important, in the rear an attachment which seems to be broken
in the middle and rises to two different levels. With a hand lens you can see
that Building No. 89 on the Perez model has two latticed windows, and that
is exactly what shows in the rear on Photograph D. I think, therefore, this is
the first photograph I have ever found of Walter Reed's laboratory at the post
hospital at Camp Columbia. There seems to be a little pen or fenced-in area
just beneath the last window on the right and on the horizon just above this
there appears another distant building. Looking at the maps of Camp Columbia
(a larger map than shown as Figure 10 of Truby's book) I identified it as
one of the non-medical buildings of Camp Columbia.

One of the few things that I have never been able to agree on with General
Truby was his identification of Figure 19 as Walter Reed's laboratory. I
enclose the complete photograph from which Figure 19 was taken - a photograph
of the Second Division Hospital, 7th Army Corps, Camp Columbia, April 1899,
but if one looks on the horizon to the rear and to the right of this little
center building, (labelled by General Truby as the surgery or Reed's labora-
tory) one can see definitely the profile of General Lee's headquarters. I
have carefully drawn two or three reconstructions and not one of them permits
me to conclude that this building faced the same direction as Building No. 89,
page 51. That is why I have never accepted it. General Truby thought that
later it might have been turned on its axis, “a simple thing to do,” but why
would anyone ask to have a building turned on its axis? Therefore, I am con-
vinced all the more that Figure 19 (opposite page 87,), General Truby's book,
was wrongly identified and that at long last we have found a photograph of
Walter Reed's laboratory, namely Photograph B.

Mr. Lambert, were you at Camp Lazear at any time? Mrs. Carroll loaned me
two additional photographs taken at Camp Lazear. One is an excellent one
of the fomites Building No. 1, a better one than I have ever seen before,
Lambert
- 4 -
April 5, 1954
The other is even more important. It is the first photograph of Camp
Lazear taken in the opposite direction of every other photograph I have ever
seen. It has always puzzled me when visiting Camp Lazear as it is today,
to note the irregularity of the terrain as compared to the apparent flat-
ness of the old Army photographs of Camp Lazear. Of course Reed himself
spoke of the “little valley” between Buildings One and Two and one old
Army photograph does show this depression readily, but I have no doubt
that when you visited Camp Lazear you were puzzled by the rough terrain.
Of course a great amount of the roughness is due to the development, over
the last 50 years or so, of the extensive quarries. This photograph shows
the existence of the “little Valley” between Buildings One and Two, so rough
that it does become quite irregular and almost hilly. That is why this one
photograph pleases me so much, because it shows this irregularity of the
land and, in addition, gives us another not-too-clear view of the unidentified
building or ruins that were near Building No. 2, which are shown in one of
the Army photographs, and the remnants of the ruins of which are still there
even though Building No. 2 is gone. As I don't believe you were at Camp
Lazear, I will not send you these two now, but if you were at Camp Lazear,
I will bring them along and we can discuss them, perhaps in a couple of
weeks (April 15) if I have the opportunity of visiting you.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
